content.title: Constitution
content.body:
CORPORATIONS ACT 2001

CONSTITUTION

OF

NEIGE INVESTMENTS PTY. LIMITED

A.C.N. 001 674 746

A COMPANY LIMITED BY SHARES

1       INTERPRETATION

Words and expressions used in this Constitution shall have the meanings defined below or elsewhere in this Constitution provided that, if there is any conflict with the definitions in the Corporations Act 2001 as amended (the Act), the words and expressions used in this Constitution shall have the meaning defined in the Act:

"ACN" means the Australian Company Number assigned to identify the Company.

"Act" means the Corporations Act 2001 (as amended from time to time).

“A membership” is the collection of rights, obligations and privileges attaching to the ownership of an Ordinary share.

"Constitution" means the provisions herein for the governance, management and conduct of the Company.

"Company" means the company registered with the ACN and the name written above (as changed from time to time).

"Director" means any director for the time being of the Company.

"Seal" means (if any seal is adopted by the Company), the common seal of the Company and includes any official seal of the Company.

"Secretary" means any person appointed to perform the duties of secretary of the Company.

“Senior member” means a sole owner of an Ordinary share whose name is registered in the Company’s share register in respect of that share; or, where an Ordinary share is owned by more than one person, the person whose name, at any given time, is the first name shown in the entry for that share in the Company’s share register.

"State" means the State of registration of the Company.

2       PRELIMINARY

2.1      The provisions of Section 141 of Part 2B.4 of the Corporations Act shall not apply to the Company.

2.2      The Company is a proprietary company in terms of section 113 of the Corporations Act and accordingly:-

(a)    The right to transfer a share and the right of a person to be registered as a shareholder is restricted to the circumstances contained in this Constitution.

(b)   The number of memberships in the Company is limited to fifty. .

(c)    Any invitation to the public to subscribe for and any offer to the public to accept subscriptions for any share in or debenture of the Company is prohibited.

(d)   Any invitation to the public to deposit money with and any offer to the public to accept deposits of money with the Company for fixed periods or payable at call whether bearing or not bearing interest is prohibited.

2.3      The provisions of the Constitution are to be read subject to the Act.

3       POWERS

The powers of the Company are those contained in the Act and provided for in the Constitution and the Company has the rights, powers and privileges of a natural person and, without limiting the generality of this clause of the Constitution, has the power:

3.1      To issue and allot fully or partly paid shares in the Company and to cancel the shares.

3.2      To issue debentures of the Company.

3.3      To distribute any of the assets of the Company among the shareholders in kind or otherwise.

3.4      To give security by charging uncalled capital.

3.5      To grant a floating charge on property of the Company.

3.6      To procure the Company to be registered or recognised as and where required as a body corporate in any place outside the State of registration.

3.7      To increase or reduce the capital and to divide the shares in the capital for the time being into several classes and to attach thereto respectively any preferential, deferred, qualified or special rights privileges or conditions as shall from time to time be determined by the Company.

3.8      To do any other act that it is authorised to do by any other law, including a law of a foreign country, notwithstanding that the Company's interests are or may not be served by doing the act.

4.      CAPITAL

The capital of the Company is three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000).

5.      LIABILITY OF SHAREHOLDERS

The liability of the shareholders is limited.

6       SHARES AND SHARE RIGHTS

6.1      The capital of the Company is divided into 150 shares of the following classes, proportions and nominal values:

50 - Ordinary shares of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) each.

50 - "A" class Preference shares of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) each.

50 - "B" class Redeemable Preference shares of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) each.

6.2      A holder of an Ordinary share shall be entitled to receive notice of meetings. and where present in person or by proxy or by attorney at any general meeting of the Company shall be entitled to vote in accordance with clause 17.16(b).

6.3      Shares of class “A” and "B" shall have no voting rights attached to them (except in relation to the operation of clause 6.8).

6.4      Where at any time there is a class of share on issue, any dividend or distribution of capitalised profits may be declared by the Company in general meeting as the Directors from time to time recommend, and,

(a)    All dividends whether interim or otherwise may be paid, and distributions of capitalised profits may be made on any class of share to the exclusion of any other class of share, and

(b)   Where any dividends are declared or distributions of capitalized profits are made on more than one class of share, the dividends or distributions may vary between classes but shall be paid in equal proportions in respect of the shares within a class.

(c)    Any resolution which declares different rates of dividend or distribution on different classes of shares or excludes a class of share from the declaration of dividend or distribution, shall be valid and binding on all members, even where the resolution is decided by the votes of members who will thereby receive a higher rate of dividend or distribution, or where such resolution was opposed by the holders of a class of share who will receive a lower rate of dividend or distribution or who will be excluded from receiving a dividend or distribution.

6.5      Should the Company be wound up or have its capital reduced, each class of share shall rank in the following descending order of priority as regards return of capital of the Company: Ordinary, "A", and "B". Any surplus assets or profits remaining after the distribution of capital shall be shared equally between Ordinary, "A" and "B" class shares.

6.6      The rights, privileges, restrictions and conditions attached to the Redeemable Preference shares are:

(a)    The holders of "B" class redeemable preference shares shall be entitled to payment of such non-cumulative dividends as the Directors may from time to time recommend and as the Company may declare under this Constitution, provided that any dividends so declared shall be at a rate not lower than that declared on any other class of share in the Company.

(b)   The Company reserves the right at any time or from time to time to redeem such of the "B" class redeemable preference shares as it may from time to time determine.

6.7      The Directors, subject to any resolution, may issue shares in the Company and attach to them preferred, deferred or other special rights or restrictions, whether with regard to dividend, voting, return of capital, use of Company property or otherwise, provided that the Directors shall not prejudice special rights previously attached to a share or class of share unless specifically authorized to do so by resolution.

6.8      The Directors may vary the rights attached to any class of share unless otherwise provided by the terms of issue of the shares in that class and whether or not the Company is being wound up, if the Directors have the consent in writing of the holders of three-quarters of the issued shares of that class, or have the authority of a special resolution passed at a separate meeting of the holders of the shares of that class.  The provisions of this Constitution relating to general meetings apply so far as they are capable of application to every such separate meeting except that a quorum is constituted by at least two persons who between them hold or represent by proxy one-third of the issued shares of the class.

6.9      The Company may buy shares of any class in itself.

6.10    Holding an Ordinary share is a necessary prerequisite to the holding of a share of any other class.  A purported sale or transfer of a share in such other class of share to a person who does not hold an Ordinary share will not be recognized by the Company.  Where the holder of an Ordinary share purports to sell or transfer an Ordinary share while retaining ownership of a share in another class he or she shall forfeit the other share to the Company and the provisions of clause 13 shall apply to the forfeited share.

7       BROKERAGE & COMMISSION

The Company may exercise the power to make payments of brokerage or commission conferred by the Act in the manner provided by the Act.  Payments by way of brokerage or commission may be satisfied by the payment of cash, by the allotment of fully or partly paid shares or partly by the payment of cash and partly by the allotment of fully or partly paid shares.

8       SHAREHOLDERS

8.1      Except as required by law, the Company shall not recognise a person as holding a share upon any trust.

8.2      The Company is not bound by or compelled in any way to recognise any interest or right whether or not the Company has been notified of any interest or right, and whether it be for an equitable, contingent, future or partial interest, in any share or part thereof or any other right in respect of a share, except an absolute beneficial right of ownership in the registered holder as provided by this Constitution or by law,

8.3      A person whose name is entered as a member in the register of members is entitled without payment to receive a certificate of registration signed in accordance with Clause 19.3.  In respect of a share or shares held jointly or severally, the Company is not bound to issue more than one certificate.

8.4      Delivery of a certificate for a share to one joint holder of the share is sufficient delivery to all such holders.

9       LIEN ON SHARES

9.1      The Company has a first and paramount lien binding on a member and the member’s estate in respect every share which is not a fully paid share, for all money, including interest, called or payable at a fixed time in respect of that share, whether presently payable or not.   The lien shall include any dividends or distributions declared in respect of a share.

9.2      The Company has a first and paramount lien binding on a member and the member’s estate with respect to a share, whether or not the share is a fully paid share, which has attracted a debt by law or pursuant to clauses 13 or 30 of the Constitution.

9.3      The Directors may at any time exempt a share wholly or in part from the provisions of this clause 9.

9.4      The Company may sell, in such manner as the Directors think fit, a share on which the Company has a lien, provided that:

(a)    Moneys in respect of the share are presently payable; and

(b)   The Company has, not less than 14 days before the date of the sale, given to the registered holder for the time being of the share or the person entitled to the share by reason of the death, mental incapacity or bankruptcy of the registered holder, a written demand for the moneys payable.

9.5      For the purpose of effecting a sale under clause 9.3, the Directors may authorise a person to transfer a share to a purchaser.   The Company shall (subject to clause 11.5) register the purchaser as the holder of the share without the purchaser being bound to see to the application of the purchase money by the Company.

9.6      The title of a purchaser to a share shall not be affected by any irregularity or invalidity in connection with the sale or transfer.

9.7      The Company shall apply the proceeds of a sale effected under clause 9 in payment of any moneys payable in respect of the share before its sale and shall pay any residue to the person registered as the holder of the share immediately before its sale. 

10     CALLS ON SHARES

10.1    The Directors may make calls on a member in respect of any money unpaid on his or her share (whether on account of the nominal value of the share or by way of premium) and not, by the terms of issue of the share, made payable at fixed times, and a member shall pay the amount called on his or her share to the Company at the time specified by the Directors.  Any call may be revoked or postponed by the Directors.

10.2    A member shall be entitled to receive at least 14 days notice of the time and amount of a call.

10.3    A call shall be deemed to have been made at the time when the resolution of the Directors authorising the call was passed and such resolution may require a call to be paid by installments.

10.4    Joint holders of a share, whether they hold their interest in the share as joint tenants or as tenants in common are jointly and severally liable to pay all calls in respect of the share.

10.5    If a call is not paid before or on the day appointed, the unpaid call shall attract interest from the day appointed for payment to the time of actual payment at such rate not exceeding 10% per annum (calculated daily by dividing 10% by 365 and charging that fraction for each day against the compounded or capitalised amount outstanding) as the Directors determine.  The Company may by special resolution passed in general meeting waive payment of interest wholly or in part.

10.6    Any sum that, by the terms of issue of a share, becomes payable on allotment or at a fixed date, whether on account of the nominal value of the share or by way of premium, shall for the purposes of this Constitution be deemed to be a call duly made and payable on the date on which by the terms of issue the sum becomes payable, and, in case of non-payment, all the relevant provisions of this Constitution including imposition of a lien, payment of interest and expenses, forfeiture and sale apply as if the sum became payable by virtue of a call duly made and notified.

10.7    The Directors may, in issuing shares, differentiate between shareholders as to the quantum of any calls on the shares and the time for payment of a call.

10.8    The Directors may accept from a member the whole or part of any amount unpaid on a share although no part of that amount has been called up.

10.9    The Directors may authorise payment by the Company of interest upon the whole or any part of an amount so accepted, until the amount becomes payable, at such rate, not exceeding the prescribed rate, as is agreed upon between Directors and the member paying the sum.

10.10  For the purposes of clause 10.9, the prescribed rate of interest is either,

(a)    If the Company has by resolution fixed a rate, the rate so fixed, or

(b)   In any other case, as provided in clause 10.5 of the Constitution.

11     TRANSFER OF SHARES

11.1    Subject to this Constitution, a member may transfer a share by instrument in writing in any usual or common form or in any other form that the Directors approve.

11.2    An instrument of transfer referred to in clause 11.1 shall be executed by or on behalf of both the transferor and the transferee.

11.3    The transferor of a share under an instrument of transfer remains the registered holder of the share until the transfer is registered and the name of the transferee is entered in the register of members in respect of the share.

11.4    The instrument of transfer must be left for registration at the registered office of the Company, together with such fee (if any) not exceeding the prescribed fee as the Directors require, accompanied by the certificate of the share to which it relates and such other information as the Directors properly require to show the right of the transferor to make the transfer, and, thereupon, the Company shall, subject to the powers vested in the Directors by the Constitution, register the transferee as a member.  The Directors shall have the power to waive the production of a share certificate provided they receive evidence satisfactory to them in their sole discretion that the certificate cannot be produced because of its loss or destruction.

11.5    The Directors may in their absolute discretion refuse to register any transfer of shares without assigning any reason for their refusal.  The Directors shall cause a notice of refusal of registration to be mailed to the transferor and the transferee within 60 days of such refusal.

11.6    Any registration of transfer may be suspended at such times, and for such periods, as the Directors from time to time determine not exceeding in the whole 60 days in any year.

11.7    It shall be the responsibility of the transferee to attend to all and any state or federal stamp duties, taxes or other costs levied or to be levied on the transfer of a share.

12     TRANSMISSION OF SHARES

12.1    Where a member dies, a surviving member, where the deceased held the share as a joint tenant, or the legal personal representative of the deceased where the deceased held the share as the sole holder or as a tenant in common, shall be the only persons recognised by the Company as having any title or interest in the shareholding, but this clause does not release the estate of the deceased from any liability attaching to the share at the time of the member’s death.

12.2    Subject to the Bankruptcy Act 1966, a person becoming entitled to a share as the consequence of the death, mental incapacity or bankruptcy of a member may, upon such information being produced as is properly required by the Directors, elect either to be registered as a member or to nominate another person to be registered as a member.

12.3    Where a person becoming entitled elects to be registered as a member he or she shall give the Company written notice of the election.

12.4    Where a person nominates another person to be registered as a member, he or she shall execute a transfer of the share to that other person.

12.5    All the limitations, restrictions and provisions of the Constitution relating to the transfer and the registration of transfer of shares are applicable to any such notice or transfer as if the death, mental incapacity or bankruptcy of the shareholder had not occurred and the notice or transfer were a transfer signed by the member.

12.6    Where a member dies, suffers mental incapacity or becomes bankrupt, his or her personal representative or the trustee of his estate, as the case may be, is, upon the production of such information as is properly required by the Directors, entitled to the same dividends and distributions, and to the same rights (whether in relation to meetings of the Company, or to voting or otherwise), as the member would have been entitled to if he or she had not died, suffered mental incapacity or become bankrupt.

12.7    Where two (2) or more persons are jointly entitled to any share as a consequence of the death or mental incapacity of a member, they shall, for the purpose of the Constitution, be deemed to be joint holders of the share.  For the purposes of this clause, where joint holders have a family or marital relationship, they shall be treated as joint tenants, otherwise they will be treated as tenants in common (in equal shares).

13     FORFEITURE OF SHARES

13.1    Where a member fails to pay either a call or an installment of a call on the day appointed for payment, the Directors may, at any time thereafter while any part of the call or installment remains unpaid, serve a notice of demand on the member requiring payment of so much of the call or installment as is unpaid, together with any interest and other costs of the Company accrued through the non-payment of the call.

13.2    The notice of demand shall name a further day (not earlier than the expiration of 14 days from the date of the notice) on or before which the payment required by the notice is to be made and shall state that, in the event of non-payment at or before the time appointed, the share in respect of which the call was made will be liable to be forfeited.

13.3    If the demands of a notice served under clauses 13.1 and 13.2 are not satisfied, any share in respect of which the notice has been given may at any time thereafter, before the payment demanded by the notice has been made, be forfeited by a resolution of the Directors.

13.4    Such a forfeiture shall include all dividends declared in respect of the forfeited share but not paid before the forfeiture.

13.5    A forfeited share may be sold or otherwise disposed of on such terms and in such manner as the Directors think fit, and, at any time before a sale or disposition, the forfeiture may be cancelled on such terms as the Directors think fit.

13.6    A person whose share has been forfeited ceases to be a member in respect of the forfeited share but remains liable to pay to the Company all money that, at the date of forfeiture, was payable to the Company in respect of the share (including interest at the rate of 10% per annum (calculated daily by dividing 10% by 365 and charging that fraction for each day against the amount outstanding) from the date of forfeiture on the money for the time being unpaid if the Directors think fit to enforce payment of the interest), but his liability ceases if and when the Company receives payment in full of all the money (including interest) so payable in respect of the share.

13.7    A statement in writing declaring that the person making the statement is a Director or a Secretary of the Company, and that a share in the Company has been duly forfeited on a date recorded in the statement, is prima facie evidence of the facts recorded in the statement as against all persons claiming to be entitled to the share.

13.8    The Company may receive the consideration (if any) given for a forfeited share on any sale of the share and may execute a transfer of the share in favour of the person to whom the share is sold.

13.9    Upon the execution of the transfer, the transferee shall be registered as the holder of the share and is not bound to see to the application of any money paid as consideration.

13.10  The title of the transferee to the share shall not be affected by an irregularity or invalidity in connection with the forfeiture, sale or transfer of the share.

13.11  The provisions of this Constitution as to forfeiture apply in the case of non-payment of any sum that by the terms of issue of a share, becomes payable at a fixed time, whether on account of the nominal value of the share or by way of premium, as if that sum had been payable by virtue of a call duly made and notified.

14.    MEMBER CONTRIBUTIONS AND LEVIES

14.1    The Company shall in each year or more often as it shall determine impose a levy on members for an amount not exceeding the sum of the reasonable expenses, charges and outgoings referred to hereafter in this clause 14.

14.2    The Directors shall, at least annually, prepare estimates of the expenses, charges and outgoings they expect to incur over the period covered by the estimates.

14.3    The Company shall, at each annual general meeting, determine, subject to clause 14.4, an estimate of the amount of money it will need to credit to the Company accounts for actual and expected expenditure, including but not limited to the following categories:

(a)    maintaining in good order and repair the Company's real and personal property.

(b)   administering and managing the company and its assets.

(c)    replacing and/or improving the Company’s real or personal property.

(d)   to meet other recurrent expenses incurred in maintaining and protecting the Company’s property and assets.

14.4    When determining an estimate of the amount to be credited to the Company’s accounts pursuant to clause 14.3, the Company shall consider, among other things, a statement of the existing financial situation of the Company, an estimate of receipts and payments, and any material presented by the Directors, including the Directors’ estimates prepared pursuant to clause 14.2.

14.5    The Company shall determine the amounts to be levied on each share as a contribution the amounts estimated as needing to be credited to the Company’s accounts.  That determination must be made at the same meeting at which those estimated amounts are determined. 

14.6    The Company shall levy the contributions determined under Clause 14.5 by serving on the Senior member a written notice of the contribution payable.

14.7    A contribution is, if the Company so determines, payable by such regular periodic installments as are specified in the determination setting the amount of the contribution.

14.8    If the Company, in any year, is subsequently faced with additional expenditure of a kind established under clause 14.3, that it cannot at once meet from the Company accounts, it shall, in order to meet the expenditure, levy on each member such contribution to the accounts as it determines at a general meeting of the Company.

14.9    Contributions levied by the Company shall be levied in equal proportions on each Ordinary share held.

14.10  If, at the time a person becomes a member, whether by transfer or transmission, the former shareholder is liable in respect of the share to pay a contribution levied on the share, the current shareholder is jointly and severally liable with the former shareholder for the payment of the contribution and for an interest incurred on the contribution.

14.11  Regular periodic contributions to the Company’s accounts are taken to have been duly levied on a member even though a notice or notices levying the contributions was or were not served on the member.

14.12  Any contribution levied by the Company becomes due and payable to the Company in accordance with the decision of the Company to make the levy.  A contribution, if not paid at the end of one month after it becomes due and payable, bears until paid interest at an annual rate of 10 per cent or, if the Company determines another rate, that other rate.   However, the Company may by special resolution determine (either generally or in a particular case) that a contribution is to bear no interest.

14.13  The Company may, by special resolution, determine (either generally or in a particular case) that a person may pay 10 per cent less of a contribution levied if the person pays the contribution before the date on which it becomes due and payable.

14.14  The Company may recover as a debt a contribution not paid at the end of one month after it becomes due and payable, together with any interest payable and the expenses of the Company incurred in recovering those amounts by action in any court of competent jurisdiction.

14.15  The Directors may invest any money in the Company’s accounts in any manner permitted by law.

15.    ALTERATION OF CAPITAL

15.1    The Company may by resolution -

(a)    Increase its authorised share capital by the creation of new shares of such number and value as is specified in the resolution.

(b)   Consolidate and divide all or any of its authorised share capital into shares of a higher number than the existing shares.

(c)    Subdivide all or any of its shares into shares of lesser value than is fixed by the Constitution but so that in the subdivision the proportion between the amount paid and the amount (if any) unpaid on each such share of a lesser value is the same as it was before the subdivision.

(d)   Cancel shares that, at the date of the passing of the resolution, have not been taken or agreed to be taken by any person or have been forfeited and reduce its authorised share capital by the amount of the shares so cancelled.

15.2    Subject to any direction that may be given by the Company in general meeting, unissued shares shall first be offered to shareholders who at the date of the offer are entitled to receive notices from the Company of general meetings and the number of shares offered in respect of each shareholding shall be in the same proportion, as nearly as circumstances allow, as the proportion of the nominal value of each shareholding to the total nominal value of the Company’s issued shares.

15.3    The offer shall be made by notice specifying the number of shares offered and a date and time at which the offer, if not accepted, will be deemed to have been declined.

15.4    Directors may issue in any manner they think beneficial to the Company any shares declined or deemed to have been declined.

15.5    Where, by reason of the proportion that shares proposed to be issued bear to shares already held, some available shares cannot be offered in accordance with clause 15.2, the Directors may issue the shares that cannot be so offered in such manner as they think beneficial to the Company.

15.6    The Company may, by special resolution, reduce its share capital, any capital redemption reserve fund or any share premium account.

16.    GENERAL MEETINGS

16.1    The Company shall hold its first annual meeting within the period required by the Act.

16.2    Any Director may, whenever he or she thinks fit, call a general meeting.

16.3    A notice of a general meeting shall specify the place, the day and the hour of meeting and, except as provided by clause 16.4, shall state the general nature of the business to be transacted at the meeting.

16.4    It is not necessary for a notice of an annual general meeting to state that the business to be transacted at the meeting includes the declaring of a dividend, the consideration of accounts and the reports of the Directors and auditors, the election or retirement of Directors or the appointment and fixing of the remuneration of the auditors.

16.5    A member who is entitled to attend and cast a vote at a meeting of the Company may appoint a person to attend and vote as the member’s proxy at the meeting.

16.6    Notice of every general meeting shall be given in the manner authorised by clause 17 of the Constitution to:

(a)    Every registered member.

(b)   Every person entitled to a share as a consequence of the death or bankruptcy of a shareholder who, but for his death or bankruptcy, would be entitled to receive notice of the meeting.

(c)    The auditor for the time being of the Company.

           No other person is entitled to receive notices of general meetings.

17     PROCEEDINGS AT GENERAL MEETINGS

17.1    No general meeting shall transact business unless a quorum of members is present.  Subject to clause 6.8 with respect to separate general meetings, and subject further to clause 17.3, six (6) members present shall constitute a quorum for any general meeting of all members entitled to vote.

17.2    For determining whether a quorum is present, a person attending as a proxy, or as a representative of a corporation that is a member, shall be deemed to be a member present in person.

17.3    If a quorum is not present within half an hour of the time appointed for the meeting,

(a)    The meeting shall be dissolved if it was called by order of the members, or, in any other case,

(b)   The meeting shall stand adjourned to such day, and at such time and place, as the Directors determine or, if no determination is made by the Directors, to the same day in the next week at the same time and place, and

(c)    If at the adjourned meeting a quorum is not present within half an hour from the time appointed for the meeting then, the number of persons needed to constitute a quorum shall be equal to the minimum number of persons allowed by the Act. Where the number of persons present is fewer than a quorum, the meeting shall be dissolved.

17.4    If the Directors have elected one of their number as Chair of their meetings, he or she shall preside as Chair at every general meeting.

17.5    Where a general meeting is held and a Chair has not been elected as provided by clause 17.4, or the Chair is not present within 15 minutes after the time appointed for the holding of the meeting or is unwilling to act, then the members present shall elect one of their number to be Chair of the meeting.

17.6    The Chair may, with the consent of any meeting at which a quorum is present, and shall, if so directed by the meeting, adjourn the meeting from time to time and from place to place, but no business shall be transacted at any adjourned meeting other than the business left unfinished at the meeting from which the adjournment took place.

17.7    Where a meeting is adjourned for 30 days or more, notice for the adjourned meeting shall be given as for the original meeting.

17.8    Except as provided by clause 17.7, it is not necessary to give any notice of an adjournment or of the business to be transacted at an adjourned meeting.

17.9    At any general meeting a resolution shall be decided on a show of hands unless a poll is (before or on the declaration of the result of the show of hands) demanded by the Chair or by at least one person present and entitled to vote.

17.10  Before a vote is taken the Chair must inform the meeting whether any proxy votes have been received and how the proxy vote is to be cast.  Where a proxy vote may be cast at the Chair's discretion, the Chair must declare how he or she proposes to exercise the vote. 

17.11  Unless a poll is demanded, a declaration by the Chair that a resolution has on a show of hands been carried unanimously, or carried by a particular majority, or lost, and the making of an entry to that effect in the minute book of the proceedings of the Company, is conclusive evidence of the fact without proof of the number or proportion of the votes recorded in favour of or against the resolution.

17.12  The demand for a poll may be withdrawn.

17.13  If a poll is duly demanded, it shall be taken in such manner (subject to clause 17.14) either at once or after an interval or adjournment or otherwise as the Chair directs, and the result of the poll shall be the resolution of the meeting at which the poll was demanded.

17.14  A poll demanded over the election of the Chair or on a question of adjournment shall be taken forthwith.

17.15  In the case of an equal number of votes being cast for and against a resolution, whether on a show of hands or on a poll, the Chair of the meeting, shall have, in addition to a deliberative vote (if any), a casting vote.

17.16  Subject clause 17.17 and to any rights or restrictions for the time being attached to any class of share,

(a)    At meetings of shareholders each shareholder may vote in person, by proxy or by attorney; and

(b)   On a show of hands or on a poll a person present may cast one (1) vote in respect of each Ordinary share held.

17.17  In the case of joint holders of a share, the vote of the Senior member who casts a vote, whether in person, by proxy or by attorney shall be accepted to the exclusion of a vote of another joint holder.

17.18  If a member is of unsound mind or is or whose estate is liable to be dealt with in any way under the law relating to mental health, his or her committee or trustee or such other person as properly appointed by law to be responsible for the management of his or her estate may exercise any rights of the member in relation to a general meeting as if the committee, trustee or other person were the member.

17.19  A member is not entitled to vote at a general meeting where any call or other moneys payable in respect of his or her shareholding remains payable.

17.20  An objection may be raised to the qualification of a voter only at the meeting or adjourned meeting at which the vote objected to is tendered, and any such objection shall be referred to the Chair of the meeting, whose decision is final. A vote not disallowed pursuant to such an objection is valid for all purposes.

17.21  An instrument appointing a proxy shall be in writing under the hand of the appointor or of his or her attorney duly authorised in writing or, if the appointor is a corporation, either under seal or under the hand of an officer or attorney duly authorised.

17.22  An instrument appointing a proxy may specify the manner in which the proxy is to vote in respect of a particular resolution and, where an instrument of proxy so provides, the proxy is not entitled to vote on the resolution except as specified in the instrument.

17.23  An instrument appointing a proxy shall be deemed to confer authority to demand, or join in demanding, a poll.

17.24  An instrument appointing a proxy shall be in the following form or in a form that is as similar to the following form as the circumstances allow:

Neige Investments Pty Limited ACN 001 674 746

I/we.....................................of ................................................... being a shareholder/shareholders of the above named company, hereby appoint

..........................................of........................................or, in his absence,

.........................................of..........................................................as my/our proxy to vote for me/us on my/our behalf at the *annual general/*general meeting of the company to be held on the .......................day of ....................... (year)................

and at any adjournment of that meeting.

# This proxy is to be exercised  * in favour of / * against the resolution.

Signed this ..........................day of ...................................... (year).........................

* Strike out whichever is not applicable.

# To be inserted if desired.

17.25  An instrument appointing a proxy shall not be treated as valid unless the instrument, and the power of attorney or other authority (if any) under which the instrument is signed or a notarially certified copy of that power or authority, is or are deposited, not less than 48 hours before the time for holding the meeting or adjourned meeting at which the person named in the instrument proposes to vote, or, in the case of a poll, not less than 24 hours before the time appointed for the taking of the poll, at the registered office, of the Company or at such other place within the State as is specified for that purpose in the notice convening the meeting.

17.26  A vote given in accordance with the terms of an instrument of proxy or of a power of attorney is valid notwithstanding the previous death or unsoundness of mind of the principal, the revocation of the instrument (or of the authority under which the instrument was executed) or of the transfer of the share in respect of which the instrument or power is given, if no intimation in writing of the death, unsoundness of mind, revocation or transfer has been received by the Company at the registered office before the commencement of the meeting or adjourned meeting at which the instrument is used or the power is exercised.

17.27  A challenge to a right to vote at a meeting of the Company may only be made at the meeting and must be determined by the Chair whose determination shall be final.

18.    APPOINTMENT, REMOVAL & REMUNERATION OF DIRECTORS

18.1    The number of Directors shall not be fewer than four (4), and shall not exceed six (6) unless determined otherwise by a resolution in general meeting of the Company.

18.2    The Directors may at any time appoint any person to be a Director, either to fill a casual vacancy or as an addition to the existing Directors, but not so that the total number of Directors at any time exceeds the number determined in accordance with this Constitution.  A person may be appointed as a Director in order to make up a quorum for a Directors’ meeting even if the total number of Directors of the Company is not enough to make up a quorum.

18.3    Any Director appointed pursuant to clause 18.2 may exercise all the powers and responsibilities of the office of director established by this Constitution but such an appointment shall expire, unless confirmed by the Company in general meeting, two (2) months after the date of the appointment.

18.4    The Company may by resolution remove any Director and may by resolution appoint another person in his or her stead.

18.5    It shall not be necessary for a person to be a member to qualify as a Director, Secretary or other officer of the Company.

18.6    The Directors shall be paid such remuneration as may be determined by the Company in general meeting.

18.7    The Directors may be paid travelling and other expenses properly incurred by them in attending and returning from meetings of the Directors or any committee of the Directors or general meetings of the Company or otherwise in connection with the business of the Company.

18.8    An office of Director becomes vacant upon the Director:

(a)    Being of unsound mind or being a person whose person or estate is liable to be dealt with in any way under the law relating to mental health;

(b)   Resigning the office by notice in writing to the Company;

(c)    being absent without the consent of the Directors from all meetings of the Directors held during a period of 12 months;

(d)   Ceasing to be a Director by operation of the Act;

(e)    Becoming bankrupt or making an arrangement or negotiating a composition with his or her creditors.

19     POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTORS

19.1    Subject to this Constitution, the Company shall be operated and managed by or under the direction of the Directors, who may pay all expenses incurred in promoting and forming the Company, and may exercise all such powers of the Company as are not required to be exercised by the Company in general meeting.

19.2    Without limiting the generality of clause 19.1, the Directors may exercise all the powers of the Company to borrow money, to charge any property or business of the Company or all or any of its uncalled capital and to issue debentures or give any other security for a debt, liability or obligation of the Company or of any other person.

19.3    Documents requiring signatures of Directors shall be executed as follows:

(a)    if the Company has resolved not to adopt a seal, the Directors shall execute all documents in accordance with the Act, and Clause 19.3 (c).

(b)   if the Company has adopted a seal, the Directors may exercise the discretion to execute any particular document either under seal, or in accordance with Clause 19.3(c).

(c)    if there are fewer than two Directors, by the signatures of the sole Director and the Secretary, or where the sole Director is also the Secretary then the words "Sole Director and Secretary" shall be applied next to the signature.

19.4    The Directors may, by power of attorney, appoint any person or persons to be the attorney or attorneys of the Company for such purposes, with such powers, authorities and discretions (being powers, authorities and discretions vested in or exercisable by the Directors), for such period and subject to such conditions as they think fit.  Such power of attorney may contain such provisions for the protection and convenience of persons dealing with the attorney as the Directors think fit and may also authorise the attorney to delegate all or any of the powers, authorities and discretions vested in him or her.

19.5    All cheques, promissory notes, bankers’ drafts, bills of exchange and other negotiable instruments, and all receipts for money paid to the Company, shall be signed, drawn, accepted, endorsed or otherwise executed, as the case may be, where the Act allows for a single director by that Director, or by any two (2) directors or in such other manner as the Directors determine.

19.6    The Directors shall arrange for minutes of meetings to be maintained in suitable minute books, and for the required company returns to be lodged, and statutory records to be kept.  The Directors shall ensure that any documents which require the signature of a director, secretary or Chair under the Act, are so signed or by any mechanical or electronic printing method, subject to the following conditions;

(a)    The Company passing a resolution of shareholders or Directors (as the circumstances require) for the singular or continuing use of such method, and

(b)   Such Director, Secretary or Chair being in agreement for his signature to be so imprinted.

20     PROCEEDINGS OF DIRECTORS

20.1    The Directors may meet together for the dispatch of business and adjourn and otherwise regulate their meetings as they think fit, and their meetings may be held by telephone or by video conferencing or by any other electronic means which the Directors decide is suitable for their purposes.

20.2    A Director may at any time, and the Secretary shall on the requisition of a Director, convene, by giving reasonable notice, a meeting of the Directors.  A Director who has appointed an alternate director may ask for the notice to be sent to the alternate director.

20.3    Subject to this Constitution, questions arising and resolutions determined at a meeting of Directors shall be decided by a majority of votes of the Directors present and voting and any such decision shall for all purposes be deemed a decision of the Directors.

20.4    No Director shall be disqualified by his or her office from holding any office or place of profit under the Company or under any company in which this company shall be a shareholder or otherwise interested or from contracting with the Company either as a vendor, purchaser or otherwise nor shall any such contract or any contract or arrangement entered into by or on behalf of the Company in which the Director shall be in any way interested be avoided nor shall any Director be liable to account to the Company for any profit arising from any such office or place of profit or realised by such contract or arrangement by reason only of such Director holding that office or of the fiduciary relations thereby established but it is declared that the nature of this interest must be disclosed by him or her in the manner required by the Act.  A Director may vote in respect of any contract or arrangement in which he or she is interested.  A Director may be appointed as a Director by whose hand and in whose presence an instrument binding the Company is to be executed, notwithstanding that he or she is interested in the contract of arrangement to which the instrument relates.

20.5    A Director may, with the approval of the other Directors, appoint a person (whether a member of the Company or not) to be an alternate director in his or her place during a nominated period.

20.6    An alternate director is entitled to notice of meetings of the Directors and, if the appointor is not present at such a meeting, is entitled to attend and vote in his or her stead.

20.7    An alternate director may exercise any powers that the appointor may exercise and the exercise of any such power by the alternate director shall be deemed to be the exercise of the power by the appointor.

20.8    The appointment of an alternate director may be terminated at any time by the appointor or by the other directors and terminates in any event if the appointor vacates office as a Director.

20.9    An appointment, or the termination of an appointment, of an alternate director shall be effected by a notice in writing signed by the Director who makes or made the appointment and served on the Company.

20.10  At a meeting of Directors, the number of Directors whose presence is necessary to constitute a quorum is three (3), or such greater number as determined by the Directors.

20.11  In the event of a vacancy or vacancies in the office of a Director or offices of Directors, the remaining Directors may act but, if the number of remaining Directors is not sufficient to constitute a quorum at a meeting of Directors, they may act only for the purpose of increasing the number of directors to a number sufficient to constitute such a quorum or of convening a general meeting of the Company.

20.12  The Directors shall elect one of their number as Chair of their meetings and may determine the period for which he or she is to hold office, and where The Chair is not present within ten (10) minutes after the time appointed for the holding of the meeting or is unwilling to act, the Directors present shall elect one of their number to be Chair of the meeting.

20.13  The Directors may delegate any of their powers to a committee or committees consisting of such of their number as they think fit, and

(a)    A committee to which any powers have been so delegated shall exercise the powers delegated in accordance with any directions of the Directors and a power so exercised shall be deemed to have been exercised by the Directors;

(b)   The members of such a committee may elect one of their number as Chair of their meetings;

(c)    A committee may meet and adjourn as it thinks proper;

(d)   Questions arising at a meeting of a committee shall be determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting;

(e)    In the case of an equal number of votes for and against a resolution, the Chair, in addition to his or her deliberative vote (if any), has a casting vote.

20.14  If all Directors have signed a document containing a statement that they are in favour of a resolution of the Directors in terms set out in the document, then, subject to clause 20.14(b), the resolution shall be deemed to have been passed at a meeting of the Directors held on the day on which the document was signed and at the time at which the document was last signed by a Director or, if the Directors signed the document on different days, on the day on which and at the time at which the document was last signed by a Director.

(a)    For the purposes of this clause 20.14, two or more separate documents containing statements in identical terms each of which is signed by one or more Directors shall together be deemed to constitute one document containing a statement in those terms signed by those Directors on the respective days on which they signed the separate documents.

(b)   A reference in clause 20.14(a) to Directors shall include only those Directors who, at a meeting of Directors, would be entitled to vote on the resolution.

20.15  All acts done by any meeting of the Directors or by a committee of Directors or by any person appointed to act as a Director are deemed to have been done by a person or persons duly appointed and qualified to be a Director, a member of a committee of Directors, or a person appointed to act as a Director notwithstanding that it is afterwards discovered that there was some defect in any such appointment or that a person so appointed was disqualified.

20.16  The Directors may from time to time appoint one of their number to the office of managing director for such periods and on such terms as they think fit, and, subject to the terms of any agreement entered into in a particular case, may revoke any such appointment.

20.17  A managing director shall, subject to the terms of any agreement entered into in a particular case, receive such remuneration (whether by way of salary, commission or participation in profits, or partly in one way and partly in another) as the Directors determine.

20.18  The Directors may, upon such terms and conditions and with such restrictions as they think fit, confer upon a managing director all or any of the powers exercised by them, provided that:

(a)    Any powers so conferred may be concurrent with, or be to the exclusion of, the powers of the Directors;

(b)   The Directors may at any time withdraw or vary any of the powers so conferred on a managing director.

20.19  The Directors, or a resolution passed by the Company in general meeting, may authorise a shareholder to inspect any books of the Company.

21     ASSOCIATE DIRECTORS

21.1    The Directors may from time to time appoint any person to be an associate director and may terminate any such appointment as they think fit.

21.2    The Directors may from time to time determine the powers, duties and remuneration of any person so appointed.

21.3    A person so appointed is not required to be a member to qualify him or her for appointment but, except by the invitation of and with the consent of the Directors, does not have any right to attend or vote at any meeting of Directors.

22     SECRETARY

The Secretary of the Company holds office on such terms and conditions as to remuneration and otherwise as the Directors determine.

23     SEAL

If the Company has resolved to adopt a seal,

(a)    the Directors shall provide for the safe custody of the seal, and

(b)   the seal shall be used only by the authority of the Directors, or of a committee of the Directors authorised by the Directors to authorise the use of the seal, and

(c)    every instrument to which the seal is affixed shall be signed in accordance with Clause 19.3 of this Constitution.

24     INSPECTION OF RECORDS

The Directors shall determine whether and to what extent, and at what time and places and under what conditions, the accounting records and other documents of the Company or any of them will be open to the inspection of members other than Directors, and a member other than a Director does not have the right to inspect any document of the Company except as provided by law or authorised by the Directors or by the Company in general meeting.

25     DIVIDENDS AND RESERVES

25.1    The Company in general meeting may declare a dividend if, and only if the Directors have recommended a dividend.

25.2    A dividend shall not exceed the amount recommended by the Directors.

25.3    The Directors may authorise the payment by the Company to shareholders of such interim dividends as appear to the Directors to be justified by the profits of the Company.

25.4    Interest is not payable by the Company in respect of any dividend.

25.5    The Directors may, before recommending any dividend, set aside out of the profits of the Company such sums as they think proper as reserves, to be applied, at the discretion of the Directors, for any purpose for which the profits of the Company may be properly applied.

(a)    Pending any such application, the reserves may, at the discretion of the Directors, be used in the business of the Company or be invested in such investments as the Directors think fit.

(b)   The Directors may carry forward so much of the profits remaining as they consider ought not to be distributed as dividends without transferring those profits to a reserve.

25.6    Subject to the rights of persons (if any) entitled to shares with special rights as to dividend, all dividends shall be declared and paid according to the amounts paid or credited as paid on the shares in respect of which the dividend is paid.

25.7    All dividends shall be apportioned and paid proportionately to the amounts paid or credited as paid on the shares during any portion or portions of the period in respect of which the dividend is paid, but, if any share is issued on terms providing that it will rank for dividend as from a particular date, that share ranks for dividend accordingly.

25.8    An amount paid or credited as paid on a share in advance of a call shall not be taken for the purposes of this regulation to be paid or credited as paid on the share.

25.9    The Directors may deduct from any dividend payable in respect of a shareholding any moneys (if any) presently payable to the Company on account of calls or otherwise in relation to the shareholding.

25.10  Any general meeting declaring a dividend may, by resolution, direct payment of the dividend wholly or partly by the distribution of specific assets, including paid up shares in, or debentures of, any other corporation, and the Directors shall give effect to such a resolution.  Where a difficulty arises in regard to such a distribution, the Directors may settle the matter as they consider expedient and fix the value for distribution of the specific assets or any part of those assets and may determine that cash payments will be made on the basis of the value so fixed in order to adjust the rights of all parties, and may vest any such specific assets in trustees as the Directors consider expedient.

25.11  Any dividend, interest or other money payable in cash in respect of shares may be paid by cheque sent through the post directed to:

(a)    The address of the member as shown in the register of members, or in the case of joint shareholders, to the address shown in the register of members as the Senior member.

(b)   To such other address as a shareholder or joint shareholders in writing directs or direct.

25.12  Any joint shareholder may give effectual receipts for any dividends, interest or other money payable in respect of a share held jointly.

26     CAPITALISATION OF PROFITS

26.1    The Company in general meeting may resolve to capitalise any sum provided that such a resolution may only be put to the meeting with the written recommendation of the Directors, being the whole or a part of the amount for the time being standing to the credit of any reserve account or the profit and loss account or otherwise available for distribution to entitled members, and that sum be applied, in any of the ways mentioned in clause 26.1(a) to 26.1(c), for the benefit of entitled members in the proportions to which they would have been entitled in a distribution of that sum by way of dividend.  The ways in which a sum may be applied for the benefit of entitled shareholders are:

(a)    In paying up any amounts unpaid on shares;

(b)   In paying up in full unissued shares or debentures to be issued to members as fully paid; or

(c)    Partly under paragraph (a) and partly under paragraph (b).

26.2    The Directors shall do all things necessary to give effect to the resolution and, in particular, to the extent necessary to adjust entitlements among members, may:

(a)    Issue fractional certificates or make cash payments in cases where shares or debentures become issuable in fractions; and

(b)   Authorise any person to make, on behalf of all the members entitled to any further shares or debentures upon the capitalisation, an agreement with the Company providing for the issue to them, credited as fully paid up of any such further shares or debentures or for the payment up by the Company on their behalf of the amounts or any part of the amounts remaining unpaid on their existing shares by the application of their respective proportions of the sum resolved to be capitalised, and any agreement made under an authority referred to in paragraph (b) is effective and binding on all the members concerned.

27     NOTICES

27.1    A notice may be given by the Company to a member either by serving it on him or her personally or by sending it to him or her by post, electronic address or facsimile to the address shown in the register of members or the postal, electronic or facsimile address provided by him or her to the Company, for the giving of notices.

27.2    Where a notice is sent by post, service of the notice shall be deemed to be effected by properly addressing, prepaying, and posting a letter containing the notice, and to have been effected, in the case of a notice of a meeting, three days after the date of its posting to any address in Australia and, in any other case, at the time at which the letter would be delivered in the ordinary course of post.  A notice sent by facsimile, or other electronic means, is taken to be given on the next business day after the day it is sent.

27.3    A notice may be given by the Company to the joint holders of a share by giving the notice to the Senior member in respect of the share.  There is no obligation to provide notice to any other of the joint holders.

27.4    A notice may be given by the Company to a person entitled to a share in consequence of the death or bankruptcy of a shareholder by serving it on him or her personally or by sending it to him or her by post addressed to him or her by name, or by the title of the representative of the deceased or assignee of the bankrupt, or by any like description, at the address (if any) in Australia supplied for the purpose by the person or, if such an address has not been supplied, at the address to which the notice might have been sent if the death or bankruptcy had not occurred.

28     WINDING UP

28.1    If the Company is wound up, the liquidator may, with the sanction of a special resolution, divide among the members in kind the whole or any part of the property of the Company and may for that purpose set such value as he or she considers fair upon any property to be so divided and may determine how the division is to be carried out as between members.

28.2    The liquidator may, with the sanction of a special resolution, vest the whole or any part of any such property in trustees upon such trusts for the benefit of members as the liquidator thinks fit, but so that no member is compelled to accept any shares or other securities in respect of which there is any liability.

29     INDEMNITY

Every officer, auditor or agent of the Company shall be indemnified out of the property of the Company against any liability incurred by him or her in their capacity as officer, auditor or agent in defending any proceedings, whether civil or criminal, in which judgment is given in their favour or in which they are acquitted or in connection with any application in relation to any such proceedings in which relief is under the Act granted to them by the court.

30     USE OF COMPANY PROPERTY

30.1    The Directors may grant permission to members to temporarily occupy and/or use company property subject to such terms and conditions, including the imposition of fees and charges, as the Directors, from time to time, in their absolute discretion, determine.

30.2    The rights and obligations of a member with respect to the use of company property shall derive from his or her shareholding, from the Constitution and from any decisions, resolutions or determinations made pursuant to the Constitution. 

30.3    The Directors shall record the general terms and conditions for the use of company property in a document entitled, "Rules for Use of Company Property".

30.4    Notwithstanding the publication of general rules pursuant to clause 30.3, the Directors may determine particular terms, conditions and restrictions for the use of company property in relation to particular usages and particular persons and the Directors may in their absolute discretion refuse permission for particular persons to use Company property.

30.5    The Directors may extend to a guest of a member the permissions granted to a member with respect to the occupation and use of Company property and where such permission is granted the member shall be responsible for ensuring that the guest acts within the terms and conditions applying to the member’s use of Company property and the member shall be liable for any damage or injury caused by the guest as if the damage or injury had been caused by the member.

30.6    The Directors may, under contract, grant to persons who are neither members nor guests of members, permission to temporarily occupy and/or use Company property and such contractual arrangements shall be, as far as it is expedient to do so, in the same terms as those applying to members under the Constitution except for such other conditions and restrictions as the Directors may think fit to impose.

30.7    Members shall, when using Company property, keep the property tidy and in good order and, fair wear and tear excepted, are liable for any damage, loss or incident associated with such use.  Should a member cause damage, loss or injury to a third party, then the member shall keep the Company indemnified, at all times, from all proceedings, judgments or claims of whatever kind, nature or consequences resulting therefrom including monetary liabilities to defend or oppose such proceedings or claims.

30.8    For the purposes of clause 30.7, the Directors may determine the amount of compensation payable to rectify an act or omission causing damage (including any future liability) and any amounts so determined by the Directors are to be paid by the member.

30.9    For the purposes of this clause 30, “member” shall be taken to include a relation, associate, guest, companion or acquaintance of the member. 

30.10  The Company shall have a first and paramount lien upon a member’s share in respect of any debts or liabilities arising under this clause 30 and such lien shall include dividends from time to time declared in respect of such shares.

30.11  Any member aggrieved by the Directors assessment of damage or loss, may apply to the Courts of New South Wales for a re-determination as to quantum or may agree with the directors upon an alternative form of arbitration or determination.

30.12  The terms and conditions attached by the Directors to the use of Company property shall insofar as it is expedient to do so include the following:

(a)    A person shall not do or permit or suffer anything to be done in or about company property or bring or keep anything therein which will in anyway obstruct or interfere with the rights to peaceful enjoyment of other users or in any way interfere with or annoy them or which will increase the rate of fire insurance on the building or the property kept therein or conflict with the laws relating to fires or with the by-laws or regulations of the Board of Fire Commissioners of New South Wales or any like authority or render void any insurance policy upon the building or any part thereof or conflict with any of the laws, by-laws, rules or ordinances in force of the Municipal Council or of the Board of Health.

(b)   A person shall not throw or allow to fall or permit to suffer to be thrown or fall any paper, rubbish, refuse or other substance whatsoever out of the windows or doors or down the staircases, passages or skylights of the building.  Any damage or costs for cleaning or repair caused by breach hereof shall be borne by the user and recoverable as if a levy were made under the provisions of the Constitution.

(c)    No animals shall be kept in or about the building without the consent of the Directors which consent may at any time be withdrawn.

(d)   A person permitted to use Company property shall ensure that any use made of the property under that permission does not cause or constitute an unreasonable detriment, nuisance, annoyance or inconvenience to other persons using Company property or occupying property in the vicinity of Company property and that Company property is not used for any illegal or immoral purpose.

(e)    A person shall park or place his or her motor vehicle only upon that portion of Company property which the Directors from time to time permit for such purposes and he or she shall observe any rules which the Directors may make concerning the parking and placing of motor vehicles on Company property.

30.13  The provisions of this clause 30 shall not in any way restrict the powers of the Directors relating to forfeiture for non-payment of any call or levy or installment or either.  In the event of the Directors resolving that in their opinion a member has failed to observe any of the conditions set out in the "Rules for Use of Company Property" and/or this clause 30 they may call upon the member to remedy the breach and if such breach be not remedied to their satisfaction within such time or upon such conditions as they shall notify to the member then the Directors shall call an extraordinary general meeting of the Company to consider whether that member shall cease to be a member of the Company.  If the meeting resolves that he or she shall cease to be a member then the following provisions shall apply:

(a)    The member may within two months from the date of the meeting or such further time as that meeting may allow but subject to this Constitution transfer his or her share(s).

(b)   If the shareholder shall not, within the time limited by the meeting, have transferred the share(s) then the Directors may find a purchaser and appoint a Director to sign all necessary documents for the purpose of transferring the share(s) and may receive the purchase price and if the shareholder does not surrender to the transferee or to the Company the Certificate/s for the share(s) then the certificate/s may be cancelled by the Directors and new Certificate/s issued and the Directors are by this clause 30 irrevocably authorised to do all such acts and is hereby constituted for such purposes as the attorney of every present and future shareholder of the Company.

(c)    After deduction of such reasonable sum as the Directors and/or the Company shall have incurred, the deduction of any moneys owing (whether due and payable or not) by the shareholder to the company and the deduction of such sum as the Directors in their absolute discretion think reasonable to cover the costs and expenses of complying with any notice served prior to the date of transfer of shares or such proportionate part of the said costs and expenses so incurred as aforesaid as would have been charged against the member had he or she continued to be a member, the balance shall be payable to the former member within one month after the date of registration of the transfer.

content.title: Director Accountabilities
content.body:
Statement of Policy

Subject: Director Accountabilities

Chairperson

  1. Select Director nominations for the Board.
  2. Manage Director Board meetings to deliver the desired membership outcomes.
  3. Schedule regular Director meetings and issue agenda.
  4. Chair AGM.
  5. Coordinate and set company policy.
  6. Update News, Rules, and other documents on the company booking web site when required.
  7. Manage bookings website system; booking confirmations and booking queries from members.

Secretary

  1. Manage company records shareholder master databases:
    1. share ownership;
    2. security key allocation;
    3. Senior member email address, postal address, and mobile number;
  2. ASIC correspondence:
    1. share sales and transfers;
    2. company officer changes (secretary, directors, director ID);
    3. shareholder changes of address (if advised to company);
    4. annual report review (ensure payment of invoice annually within lodgement times to avoid penalty.)
  3. Manage company correspondence with Senior Members.
  4. Insurance responsibility:
    1. annual building and liability insurance;
    2. three-yearly building valuations;
    3. Officer holders’ annual indemnity.
  5. Coordinate AGM date with Directors:
    1. prepare AGM agenda;
    2. issue “Notice of AGM”;
    3. coordinate reports for issue (in particular Treasurer reports and Budget);
    4. coordinate proxies;
    5. record AGM attendance;
    6. minute AGM.
  6. Advise Directors of company Director obligations as required.
  7. Maintain hard copy folders of selected correspondence:
    1. AGMs;
    2. Director’s meeting minutes;
    3. Insurances;
    4. Building valuations reports etc.(keep five years minimum).
  8. Manage:
    1. share sales process;
    2. maintain buyer and seller registers;
    3. maintain company share transfer form and process;
    4. maintain list of interested buyers and sellers;
    5. maintain average sale price of last three shares for public distribution to Directors plus share buyers and sellers.
  9. Manage master hard copy share register.
  10. Manage master soft copy share and security key register.
  11. Minute Directors (and other) company meetings.
  12. Manage Dropbox- subset of company records for Director shared common information only

Treasurer

  1. Manage bank account/s; PayPal account; internet banking
  2. Propose investment options for savings
  3. Address for utility periodic bills delivery and invoice payment
    1. water rates
    2. council rates
    3. sewerage rates
    4. gas
    5. electricity
    6. NBN
  4. Pay all bills as they arrive in a timely manner ensuring adequate cash flow.
  5. Manage member levy invoicing; follow up non-payers; manage late fees.
  6. Manage web site (member password queries and initial web entry).
  7. Preparation of annual accounts and liaison with company Accountant.
  8. Tax Office liaison and payments (PAYG installments); Land Tax.
  9. Maintain booking system payment platform relationship (via Treasurer)
  10. Manage web site hosting account and annual fee payment (via Treasurer).
  11. Propose and update booking fees annually with Board.
  12. Manage booking Excel spreadsheet.
  13. Prepare annual budget for AGM.
  14. Issue financial report to Director for review at Directors’ meetings.
  15. Manage on-site security Camera system.

Cleaning Coordinator

  1. Manage cleaning schedule with chosen cleaners and interfacing to members when required.
  2. Manage lawn mowing schedule and gardening maintenance schedule.
  3. Maintain Member “housekeeping” tasks list on room doors and notice board.
  4. Update booking “cleaning” spreadsheet.
  5. Coordinate selection and delivery of bulk purchased cleaning supplies and consumables to lodge.

Neige Facebook Member Group Coordinator

  1. Setup a member Facebook group based on voluntary participation, to enhance social interaction of the membership base.
  2. Implement posting “guidelines” and undertake posted content review ongoing for compliance with guidelines.
  3. Add content as required advising members of administrative and social events.

Maintenance Coordinator

  1. Coordinate project works.
  2. Maintain records of all maintenance works pending approval; approved and completed.
  3. Provide recommendations for funding approval.
  4. Coordinate firewood delivery.
  5. Manage key safe for trusted trades people only and emergency access.

content.title: Transfer of Shares
content.body:
Statement of Policy

Subject:  Policy on Transfer or Transmission of shares in Neige Investments Pty Ltd

This policy describes the process to transfer of a share in Neige Investments Pty Ltd under two conditions:

  • Sale of a Share from an existing shareholder to a new shareholder
  • Transmission of a Share as part of a deceased estate.

Transfer of shares is governed in our Constitution by clause 11 (share sale by shareholder) and clause 12 (transmission as part of the estate of a member who has died). This policy describes the process for either circumstance.

fields.object_str: ADVICE FOR TRANSFERRING A SHARE IN NEIGE

content.title: ADVICE FOR TRANSFERRING A SHARE IN NEIGE
content.draft_title: ADVICE FOR TRANSFERRING A SHARE IN NEIGE
content.body:
Statement of Policy

Subject: ADVICE FOR TRANSFERRING A SHARE IN NEIGE

Neige Investments Pty Ltd is a NSW registered private (unlisted) company limited to 50 shares in its Constitution. Share transfers must only be transacted using the company’s share transfer form available on request from the Secretary. The company Secretary can assist buyers and sellers to make contact, and can provide guidance on completing the formal transfer documents.

A share transfer will only be registered by the company if the buyer is a person. Shares cannot be registered by a trust, company, superannuation fund, or the name of an estate or deceased person. Prerequisites for share registration approval include, but are not limited to; receipt of a Share Transfer Form compliant with completion instructions; and approval of the buyer by the company’s Board of Directors as required by clause 11 of Neige Constitution.

A share transfer will require the buyer(s) to nominate one person to be considered the “Senior Member” and this person will be the only person registered on the Neige books as being the listed Senior Member.

A share transfer is a private arrangement between the seller and buyer. As a service to sellers and prospective buyers, the Secretary maintains a list of people who have advised the company they are interested in purchasing a share.

It is up to the buyer and seller to negotiate the share sale price. This does not involve the company, however, as a guide to the market price, the Secretary will on request, provide the seller and buyer the average price of the last three share sales and the most recent insurance valuation of the property.

The Company Constitution and Policies for use of company property are available on the Neige website. Sellers may provide these policies to prospective buyers to inform them of their privileges and obligations as a Neige shareholder.

It is strongly suggested the buyer seek written confirmation from the company Secretary as to the exact registered ownership details of the share number for sale and to confirm there are no outstanding moneys due to the Company relating to that Share.

The seller will confirm to the secretary if they are still in possession of a security door key. If not a fee of $170 for key replacement will be added to the sellers account, and the buyer notified of this debt. Each share is entitled to one door key only.

Once a price has been agreed between the seller and buyer, the seller should contact the Secretary to obtain a Share Transfer Form. The seller should then complete and sign their section of the form (notes are attached to the form to assist). All company registered owners of that share must sign the seller’s section of the form. [If the share is a deceased estate, contact the Secretary]. The seller then sends the form to the buyer with a copy to the Secretary who can assist with identifying any completion errors. The seller must also return their security key via registered post in a padded bag at their own expense to the Secretary at this time.

No funds for the share purchase should be transferred by the buyer until the Secretary provides written approval that the share transfer has been approved by the company Board of Directors and the Share Transfer Form has been correctly executed [refer above note] by both seller and buyer.

The buyer (“Senior Member”) should then complete their section of the Share Transfer Form; ensuring only one buyer name and signature are used on the form. The form is then returned via Registered mail, to the Secretary.

The Secretary will write to the buyer and provide, if appropriate, written approval that the share transfer has been approved by the company Board of Directors and that the Share Transfer Form has been correctly completed. The Secretary will then advise the buyer that share purchase funds may be transferred to the seller.

If the Board of Directors decline to approve the buyer (no reasons need be given); or the Share Transfer Form is not correctly completed, the Secretary will advise buyer and sellers and suggest the action which needs to be taken.

Following share sale approval in writing by the Secretary, the seller must advise the company Secretary in writing when the share purchase funds have been received. Once financial settlement has occurred the Secretary will change ownership registration of the share in the Company's share register and notify ASIC.

The Secretary will advise the buyer in writing of completion of share transfer and registration; provide a door security key and other introductory information.

The company booking IT system manager and treasurer will set up an account on the company’s web-based booking system in the buyer’s name and email address and advise the buyer. The buyer can then book accommodation and commence use of the lodge.
